conclusion: A change in magnetic flux through the square frame – hence an induced current – only occurs while different parts of the loop are inside and outside the field.

premise: A change in magnetic flux through the square frame – hence an induced current – only occurs while different parts of the loop are inside and outside the field.
conclusion: An induced current occurs twice: while the loop is entering the field and while the loop is leaving the field.

premise: An induced current occurs twice: while the loop is entering the field and while the loop is leaving the field.
conclusion: Each of those two stages lasts for the time it takes the loop to travel a distance equal to its own side length l.
The distance between the leading and trailing edges of the square is l.

premise: With a constant speed v, the time for one stage is l / v.
conclusion: The time for one stage is l / v.

premise: The time for one stage is l / v.
conclusion: The total time during which an induced current exists is the sum of both stages: t = l / v + l / v = 2l / v.
